project_metadata.paper_title: Creating large, high-quality geospatial datasets from historical maps using novice volunteers
project_metadata.discipline: landscape archaeology / digital humanities / GIS / crowdsourcing
project_metadata.research_context: The Tundzha Regional Archaeological Project (TRAP) in Bulgaria digitized burial mounds from Soviet military topographic maps during 2017-2018 archaeological fieldwork using customized mobile GIS (FAIMS Mobile) with undergraduate field school participants as volunteer digitizers.

location.study_area: Yambol region and Kazanlak Valley, Bulgaria
location.map_coverage: over 20,000 sq km of southeast Bulgaria

resources.volunteers: Undergraduate students from associated field school

track_record.prior_mounds_catalogued: 773 mounds in Kazanlak Valley (2008-2016), 431 mounds in Yambol region (2008-2016)
track_record.prior_methods: pedestrian surface survey supported by manual digitization of satellite imagery and maps
track_record.2010_desktop_GIS_attempt: 915 features produced but approach unsuccessful due to volunteer attrition and high support needs

evidence.evidence_text: 10,827 mound features digitized from Soviet military topographic maps
evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile was used to digitise 10,827 mound features from Soviet military topographic maps.
This digitisation required 241 person-hours (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers), with an error rate under 6%.
This digitisation required 241 person-hours (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers), with an error rate under 6%.
This digitisation required 241 person-hours (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers), with an error rate under 6%.
This digitisation required 241 person-hours (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers), with an error rate under 6%.

evidence.evidence_text: Dataset was consistent, well-documented, and ready for analysis with a few hours of processing
evidence.verbatim_quote: The resulting dataset was consistent, well-documented, and ready for analysis with a few hours of processing.

evidence.evidence_text: Digitization undertaken as a secondary activity on a landscape archaeology project focusing on pedestrian feature survey
evidence.verbatim_quote: Digitisation was undertaken as a secondary activity on a landscape archaeology project focusing on pedestrian feature survey.

evidence.evidence_text: Undergraduates in the associated field school digitised data from maps using a system repurposed from other project activities
evidence.verbatim_quote: Undergraduates in the associated field school digitised data from maps using a system repurposed from other project activities.

evidence.evidence_text: Approach required little training or supervision of students
evidence.verbatim_quote: Compared to manual digitisation approaches based on desktop GIS, it required little training or supervision of students, used open-source software and low-cost equipment, yet produced a large, accurate, analysis-ready dataset.

evidence.evidence_text: Used open-source software and low-cost equipment
evidence.verbatim_quote: Compared to manual digitisation approaches based on desktop GIS, it required little training or supervision of students, used open-source software and low-cost equipment, yet produced a large, accurate, analysis-ready dataset.

evidence.evidence_text: Produced a large, accurate, analysis-ready dataset
evidence.verbatim_quote: Compared to manual digitisation approaches based on desktop GIS, it required little training or supervision of students, used open-source software and low-cost equipment, yet produced a large, accurate, analysis-ready dataset.

claims.claim_text: The crowdsourcing approach produced a large (>10,000 features), high-quality (<6% error rate) geospatial dataset from historical maps
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile was used to digitise 10,827 mound features from Soviet military topographic maps. This digitisation required 241 person-hours (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers), with an error rate under 6%.

claims.claim_text: Crowdsourcing scales better than direct digitisation by experts
claims.verbatim_quote: Crowdsourcing scales better than direct digitisation by experts, but requires an appropriate platform and the technical skills to adapt it.

claims.claim_text: The resulting dataset was consistent, well-documented, and ready for analysis with minimal post-processing
claims.verbatim_quote: The resulting dataset was consistent, well-documented, and ready for analysis with a few hours of processing.

claims.claim_text: A conservative estimate based on our work suggests our crowdsourcing approach is most efficient for digitisation projects of 10,000–60,000 features
claims.verbatim_quote: A conservative estimate based on our work suggests our crowdsourcing approach is most efficient for digitisation projects of 10,000–60,000 features, but may offer advantages for datasets as small as a few hundred records.

claims.claim_text: The crowdsourcing approach may offer advantages for datasets as small as a few hundred records
claims.verbatim_quote: A conservative estimate based on our work suggests our crowdsourcing approach is most efficient for digitisation projects of 10,000–60,000 features, but may offer advantages for datasets as small as a few hundred records.

claims.claim_text: Systems designed for field data collection, running on mobile devices, can be profitably customised to serve as participatory geospatial data systems accessible to novice volunteers
claims.verbatim_quote: Furthermore, it indicates that systems designed for field data collection, running on mobile devices, can be profitably customised to serve as participatory geospatial data systems accessible to novice volunteers.

claims.claim_text: The value of this approach lies in the unanticipated success of a minimally resourced digitisation effort
claims.verbatim_quote: The value of this approach lies in the unanticipated success of a minimally resourced digitisation effort, as well as the resulting dataset's value for archaeological research and cultural heritage management.

claims.claim_text: The approach complements Machine Learning (ML) in that it requires less technical expertise, time, and resourcing to undertake
claims.verbatim_quote: It complements Machine Learning (ML) and other automated approaches in that it requires less technical expertise, time, and resourcing to undertake.

claims.claim_text: The crowdsourcing approach is suitable for projects working with small to mid-sized data sources (100s–10,000s of features) that do not warrant the investment needed for successful ML-based data extraction
claims.verbatim_quote: Such an approach is suitable for projects working with small to mid-sized data sources (100s–10,000s of features) that do not warrant the investment needed for successful ML-based data extraction - as well as for exploratory work preceding automated analyses or the production of the training and quality assurance datasets needed for ML.

claims.claim_text: The approach shows promise as a low-cost means of extracting locations and other data from historical maps concerning endangered and poorly documented material remains
claims.verbatim_quote: As such, it shows promise as a low-cost means of extracting locations and other data from historical maps concerning endangered and poorly documented material remains.

claims.claim_text: The approach can be replicated using other mobile GIS systems, scaled up, or applied to other types of archaeological features
claims.verbatim_quote: The approach taken here can be replicated using other mobile GIS systems, scaled up, or applied to other types of archaeological features.

claims.claim_text: The crowdsourcing approach required little training or supervision of students compared to desktop GIS approaches
claims.verbatim_quote: Compared to manual digitisation approaches based on desktop GIS, it required little training or supervision of students, used open-source software and low-cost equipment, yet produced a large, accurate, analysis-ready dataset.

claims.claim_text: The digitization was undertaken as a secondary activity using a system repurposed from other project activities
claims.verbatim_quote: Digitisation was undertaken as a secondary activity on a landscape archaeology project focusing on pedestrian feature survey. Undergraduates in the associated field school digitised data from maps using a system repurposed from other project activities.

claims.claim_text: The approach used open-source software and low-cost equipment
claims.verbatim_quote: Compared to manual digitisation approaches based on desktop GIS, it required little training or supervision of students, used open-source software and low-cost equipment, yet produced a large, accurate, analysis-ready dataset.

claims.claim_text: Automatic extraction using Machine Learning (ML) requires extensive preparation and expertise
claims.verbatim_quote: Automatic extraction using Machine Learning (ML) requires extensive preparation and expertise.

extraction_notes.extraction_strategy: Liberal extraction with over-capture - Pass 1, section-by-section approach
known_uncertainties: Error rate stated as 'under 6%' - exact figure not given in Abstract/Intro
Conservative estimate methodology not detailed in Abstract/Intro
